text: amazon Web Services has helped us quite
significantly in our journey to building
awesome products for our customers but
we're also have become incredibly agile
in how we're able to deliver and
maintain these products in the cloud i'm
Victor Rodriguez and I'm the chief
software architect at Klair klair is an
implantable hearing solutions medical
device company we have over 400,000
recipients worldwide and we essentially
provide hearing solutions for profoundly
to severely deaf one is for neurosential
hearing loss and that is a coar implant
that's an implantable device and that
essentially replaces the function of the
coia the other type is called a bone
anchored hearing aid and more commonly
known as the blah and effectively what
that does it restores conductive hearing
loss in the past a recipient would
contact Klair for a particular problem
and that problem sometimes turned out to
be something that was wrong with their
external device that required
replacement and we would contact the
clinician in order to replace the part
that the recipient is needing to have
replaced and that process was sometimes
quite frustrating for the recipient
because we couldn't tell how long it
would take and what we did is through
Amazon Web Services produced an
application stack that enable us to
automate that process so today we have
this product called Klay Link that runs
on Amazon Web Services that keeps that
data in synchrony with data that's at at
KIA we chose AWS largely because they
were able to provide services that were
both agile and flexible and we were able
to build systems that we could not think
about the the grunt work that usually is
synonymous with on premise um IT
infrastructure and that's one of the
beautiful things about Amazon Web
Services a lot of the services you can
actually incorporate into your
application stack so that you're
essentially partitioning your solution
to minimize the points of failure a as
well as to you know build robust systems
that can scale there was a lot of
developer enthusiasm within the
organization for AWS it was one of those
cool things that the developers loved
the fact that you can experiment even at
the very last moment where you can spin
up environments to test one particular
facet of your solution that you think
you might want to concentrate on makes
you do it more often and makes you a lot
more comfortable with making those types
of changes whereas previously you'd be
hesitant largely based on the amount of
time and just the risk involved in
putting something like that into place
in the past it used to take anything
between 24 hours to sometimes a week
depending on whether or not we could
actually contact the clinician we've
improved that process almost guaranteed
that you know you'll get that
replacement within 24 hours and we
minimize the amount of time that our
customers are off the air where they're
unable to hear
[Music]
